about.disclaimer: This is a demo. For real projects, validate content with local stakeholders and ethics/IRB guidelines.

indicator_snippets.name: Primary care access
indicator_snippets.metric: % HH within 1km or 20-min walk of primary care

indicator_snippets.name: Mobility burden
indicator_snippets.metric: Median commute time to essential services (min)

faq.what is sdhe: SDHE = Social Determinants of Health Equity. It organizes structural drivers like income, housing, environment, and access to care to design targeted, fair interventions.
faq.what is brom: BROM = Beneficiary-Reported Outcome Measures. Short, recurring surveys that track perceived change (e.g., stress, safety, access) in beneficiaries’ own words/scores.
faq.which countries: The demo targets Southeast Asia—Thailand, Philippines, Myanmar, Vietnam, Indonesia—adapting to city/district contexts.
faq.privacy: Use anonymized data and get consent. Align with local IRB/ethics and data protection rules (e.g., PDPA).

climate justice.name: Heat risk exposure
climate justice.metric: # days > city heat threshold; households lacking cooling/adaptation

climate justice.name: Mobility time burden to essentials
climate justice.metric: Median minutes to clinic/market/school; off-peak vs peak

climate justice.name: Primary care access
climate justice.metric: % HH within 1km/20-min walk of primary care

artifacts: Beneficiary story (Most Significant Change) w/ consent
District-level policy note with 3 asks and cost–benefit
cadence: Quarterly: impact brief with BROM changes
tips: Pair a structural indicator (SDHE) with a BROM perception change.
Use clear denominators (per HH, per block, per school).
Consent & PDPA: anonymize and store separately.

notes: Schedule data collection at convenient times; provide childcare if possible.
Use female enumerators or trusted community workers where appropriate.
Combine perception (BROM) with exposure/access indicators to show pathway.
